description.content:
Last Updated July 2025

You can use Oracle REST APIs to view and manage data stored in Oracle Supply Chain Management Cloud.

Whether you're experienced with or new to REST, use this guide to find what you need, including:

  • A quick start that walks you through a simple request example.
  • Detailed descriptions for each REST API resource.

When this parameter is provided, the specified children are included in the resource payload (instead of just a link). The value of this query parameter is "all" or "". More than one child can be specified using comma as a separator. Example: ?expand=Employees,Localizations. Nested children can also be provided following the format "Child.NestedChild" (Example: ?expand=Employees.Managers). If a nested child is provided (Example: Employees.Managers), the missing children will be processed implicitly. For example, "?expand=Employees.Managers" is the same as "?expand=Employees,Employees.Managers" (which will expand Employees and Managers).

This parameter filters the resource fields. Only the specified fields are returned, which means that if no fields are specified, no fields are returned (useful to get only the links). If an indirect child resource is provided (Example: Employees.Managers), the missing children will be processed implicitly. For example, "?fields=Employees.Managers:Empname" is the same as "?fields=;Employees:;Employees.Managers:Empname" (which will only return the "Empname" field for Managers). the value of this query parameter is a list of resource fields. The attribute can be a direct (Example: Employees) or indirect (Example: Employees.Managers) child. It cannot be combined with expand query parameter. If both are provided, only fields will be considered.

Format: ?fields=Attribute1,Attribute2

Format for fields in child resource: ?fields=Accessor1:Attribute1,Attribute2
The resource item payload will be filtered in order to contain only data (no links section, for example).

This parameter specifies dependencies which are fields that are set before and rolled back after generating the response. Generally they are used to preview the effects of an attribute change. The fields specified in this parameter are always set in the resource instance in question. When a child resource collection is requested and the parameter is set, the fields will be set in the parent resource instance before generating the resource collection payload. The value of this query parameter is a set of dependency fields. Example: dependency=ProductId=2

Format: <attr1>=<val1>,<attr2>=<value2>

This parameter can be used to show only certain links while accessing a singular resource or a resource collection. The parameter value format is a comma-separated list of : <link_relation>

Example:
self,canonical

(Required) The value of this parameter could be a hash of the key that is used to uniquely identify the resource item. The client should not generate the hash key value.  Instead, the client should query on the collection resource with a filter to navigate to a specific resource item. For example: products?q=InventoryItemId=<value1>
The protocol version between a REST client and service. If the client does not specify this header in the request the server will pick a default version for the API.

If the REST API supports runtime customizations, the shape of the service may change during runtime. The REST client may isolate itself from these changes or choose to interact with the latest version of the API by specifying this header. For example: Metadata-Context:sandbox="TrackEmployeeFeature".

The resource item payload will be filtered in order to contain only data (no links section, for example).

This parameter specifies dependencies which are fields that are set before and rolled back after generating the response. Generally they are used to preview the effects of an attribute change. The fields specified in this parameter are always set in the resource instance in question. When a child resource collection is requested and the parameter is set, the fields will be set in the parent resource instance before generating the resource collection payload. The value of this query parameter is a set of dependency fields. Example: dependency=ProductId=2

Format: <attr1>=<val1>,<attr2>=<value2>

This parameter can be used to show only certain links while accessing a singular resource or a resource collection. The parameter value format is a comma-separated list of : <link_relation>

Example:
self,canonical
This parameter restricts the number of resources returned inside the resource collection. If the limit exceeds the resource count then the framework will only return the available resources.
Used to define the starting position of the resource collection. If offset exceeds the resource count then no resources are returned. Default value is 0.
The resource collection representation will include the "estimated row count" when "?totalResults=true", otherwise the count is not included.  The default value is "false".

This query parameter defines the where clause. The resource collection will be queried using the provided expressions. The value of this query parameter is one or more expressions. Example: ?q=Deptno>=10 and <= 30;Loc!=NY

Format: ?q=expression1;expression2

You can use these queryable attributes to filter this collection resource using the q query parameter:
  • AttachCategoryId; integer; Unique identifier of attachment category.
  • AttachmentCategoryCode; string; Code of the attachment category.
  • AttachmentCategoryName; string; Name of the attachment category.
  • ClassificationId; string; Internal name of an item class.
  • CreationDate; string; Who column: Indicates the date and time of the record creation.
  • CurrentItemClassId; string; Unique identifier of current item class.
  • EndDate; string; End date of the association between the attachment category and item class.
  • EntityName; string; Entity name of the attachment category.
  • Inherited; string; Flag indicating whether the record is inherited from one of the item class in its hierarchy
  • ItemClassCode; string; Internal name for Item Class.
  • LastUpdateDate; string; Who column: Indicates the date and time the record was last updated.
  • ObjName; string; Attachment internal attribute, always pass 'EGO_CATALOG_GROUP' as value.
  • StartDate; string; Start date of the association between the attachment category and item class.

This parameter orders a resource collection based on the specified fields.  The parameter value is a comma-separated string of attribute names, each optionally followed by a colon and "asc" or "desc".  Specify "asc" for ascending and "desc" for descending. The default value is "asc".  For example, ?orderBy=field1:asc,field2:desc

Used as a predefined finder to search the collection.

Format ?finder=<finderName>;<variableName>=<variableValue>,<variableName2>=<variableValue2>

The following are the available finder names and corresponding finder variables

  • ItemClassAttachmentCategoriesAltKey
    Finder Variables
    • AttachCategoryId; integer; Value that uniquely identifies the attachment category.
    • ClassificationId; string;
    • ObjName; string; Value that uniquely identifies the object name.
  • PrimaryKey Finds the item class attachment category by primary key criteria.
    Finder Variables
    • AttachCategoryId; integer; Value that uniquely identifies the attachment category.
    • ClassificationId; string; Value that uniquely identifies the item classification.
    • ObjName; string; Value that uniquely identifies the object name.

(Required) The value of this parameter could be a hash of the key that is used to uniquely identify the resource item. The client should not generate the hash key value.  Instead, the client should query on the collection resource with a filter to navigate to a specific resource item. For example: products?q=InventoryItemId=<value1>
The protocol version between a REST client and service. If the client does not specify this header in the request the server will pick a default version for the API.

If the REST API supports runtime customizations, the shape of the service may change during runtime. The REST client may isolate itself from these changes or choose to interact with the latest version of the API by specifying this header. For example: Metadata-Context:sandbox="TrackEmployeeFeature".

Instead, the client should query on the collection resource with a filter to navigate to a specific resource item. For example: products?q=InventoryItemId=<value1>

(Required) This is the hash key of the attributes which make up the composite key--- ObjName, ClassificationId and AttachCategoryId ---for the Attachment Categories resource and used to uniquely identify an instance of Attachment Categories. The client should not generate the hash key value. Instead, the client should query on the Attachment Categories collection resource with a filter on the primary key values in order to navigate to a specific instance of Attachment Categories.

For example: ItemClassAttachmentCategories?q=ObjName=<value1>;ClassificationId=<value2>;AttachCategoryId=<value3>
The protocol version between a REST client and service. If the client does not specify this header in the request the server will pick a default version for the API.

If the REST API supports runtime customizations, the shape of the service may change during runtime. The REST client may isolate itself from these changes or choose to interact with the latest version of the API by specifying this header. For example: Metadata-Context:sandbox="TrackEmployeeFeature".

You can use these queryable attributes to filter this collection resource using the q query parameter:
  • EndDate; string; Date when the lifecycle phase ends.
  • ItemClass; string; Name of the item class.
  • PhaseCode; string; Value that identifies the lifecycle phase.
  • PhaseName; string; Name of the lifecycle phase.
  • PhaseSequence; integer; Sequence number of the lifecycle phase.
  • PhaseType; string; Type of life cycle phase.
  • StartDate; string; Date when the lifecycle phase begins.

This parameter orders a resource collection based on the specified fields.  The parameter value is a comma-separated string of attribute names, each optionally followed by a colon and "asc" or "desc".  Specify "asc" for ascending and "desc" for descending. The default value is "asc".  For example, ?orderBy=field1:asc,field2:desc

Used as a predefined finder to search the collection.

Format ?finder=<finderName>;<variableName>=<variableValue>,<variableName2>=<variableValue2>

The following are the available finder names and corresponding finder variables

  • ItemClassPhasesVOAltKey
    Finder Variables
    • PhaseCode; string; Value that identifies the lifecycle phase.
    • PhaseSequence; integer;
    • PhaseType; string;
  • NextLifecyclePhasesFinder Find lifecycle phases that come after the lifecycle phase.
    Finder Variables
    • PhaseCode; string; Value that identifies the lifecycle phase.
    • PhaseName; string; Name of the lifecycle phase.
  • PrimaryKey Find lifecycle phases according to the primary key criteria.
    Finder Variables
    • CategoryId; integer; Name of the item class.
    • PhaseCode; string; Value that identifies the lifecycle phase.

(Required) The value of this parameter could be a hash of the key that is used to uniquely identify the resource item. The client should not generate the hash key value.  Instead, the client should query on the collection resource with a filter to navigate to a specific resource item. For example: products?q=InventoryItemId=<value1>

If the REST API supports runtime customizations, the shape of the service may change during runtime. The REST client may isolate itself from these changes or choose to interact with the latest version of the API by specifying this header. For example: Metadata-Context:sandbox="TrackEmployeeFeature".

  • StartDate; string; Date when the lifecycle phase begins.

This parameter orders a resource collection based on the specified fields.  The parameter value is a comma-separated string of attribute names, each optionally followed by a colon and "asc" or "desc".  Specify "asc" for ascending and "desc" for descending. The default value is "asc".  For example, ?orderBy=field1:asc,field2:desc

Used as a predefined finder to search the collection.

Format ?finder=<finderName>;<variableName>=<variableValue>,<variableName2>=<variableValue2>

The following are the available finder names and corresponding finder variables

  • ItemClassPhasesVOAltKey
    Finder Variables
    • PhaseCode; string; Value that identifies the lifecycle phase.
    • PhaseSequence; integer;
    • PhaseType; string;
  • NextLifecyclePhasesFinder Find lifecycle phases that come after the lifecycle phase.
    Finder Variables
    • PhaseCode; string; Value that identifies the lifecycle phase.
    • PhaseName; string; Name of the lifecycle phase.
  • PrimaryKey Find lifecycle phases according to the primary key criteria.
    Finder Variables
    • CategoryId; integer; Name of the item class.
    • PhaseCode; string; Value that identifies the lifecycle phase.
The protocol version between a REST client and service. If the client does not specify this header in the request the server will pick a default version for the API.

If the REST API supports runtime customizations, the shape of the service may change during runtime. The REST client may isolate itself from these changes or choose to interact with the latest version of the API by specifying this header. For example: Metadata-Context:sandbox="TrackEmployeeFeature".

When this parameter is provided, the specified children are included in the resource payload (instead of just a link). The value of this query parameter is "all" or "". More than one child can be specified using comma as a separator. Example: ?expand=Employees,Localizations. Nested children can also be provided following the format "Child.NestedChild" (Example: ?expand=Employees.Managers). If a nested child is provided (Example: Employees.Managers), the missing children will be processed implicitly. For example, "?expand=Employees.Managers" is the same as "?expand=Employees,Employees.Managers" (which will expand Employees and Managers).

This parameter filters the resource fields. Only the specified fields are returned, which means that if no fields are specified, no fields are returned (useful to get only the links). If an indirect child resource is provided (Example: Employees.Managers), the missing children will be processed implicitly. For example, "?fields=Employees.Managers:Empname" is the same as "?fields=;Employees:;Employees.Managers:Empname" (which will only return the "Empname" field for Managers). the value of this query parameter is a list of resource fields. The attribute can be a direct (Example: Employees) or indirect (Example: Employees.Managers) child. It cannot be combined with expand query parameter. If both are provided, only fields will be considered.

Format: ?fields=Attribute1,Attribute2

Format for fields in child resource: ?fields=Accessor1:Attribute1,Attribute2
The resource item payload will be filtered in order to contain only data (no links section, for example).

This parameter specifies dependencies which are fields that are set before and rolled back after generating the response. Generally they are used to preview the effects of an attribute change. The fields specified in this parameter are always set in the resource instance in question. When a child resource collection is requested and the parameter is set, the fields will be set in the parent resource instance before generating the resource collection payload. The value of this query parameter is a set of dependency fields. Example: dependency=ProductId=2

Format: <attr1>=<val1>,<attr2>=<value2>

This parameter can be used to show only certain links while accessing a singular resource or a resource collection. The parameter value format is a comma-separated list of : <link_relation>

Example:
self,canonical

(Required) The value of this parameter could be a hash of the key that is used to uniquely identify the resource item. The client should not generate the hash key value.  Instead, the client should query on the collection resource with a filter to navigate to a specific resource item. For example: products?q=InventoryItemId=<value1>

(Required) This is the hash key of the attributes which make up the composite key--- CategoryId and PhaseCode ---for the Lifecycle Phases resource and used to uniquely identify an instance of Lifecycle Phases. The client should not generate the hash key value. Instead, the client should query on the Lifecycle Phases collection resource with a filter on the primary key values in order to navigate to a specific instance of Lifecycle Phases.

For example: ItemClassPhases?q=CategoryId=<value1>;PhaseCode=<value2>

For example: Metadata-Context:sandbox="TrackEmployeeFeature".

Example:

This parameter restricts the number of resources returned inside the resource collection. If the limit exceeds the resource count then the framework will only return the available resources.
Used to define the starting position of the resource collection. If offset exceeds the resource count then no resources are returned. Default value is 0.
The resource collection representation will include the "estimated row count" when "?totalResults=true", otherwise the count is not included.  The default value is "false".

This query parameter defines the where clause. The resource collection will be queried using the provided expressions. The value of this query parameter is one or more expressions. Example: ?q=Deptno>=10 and <= 30;Loc!=NY

Format: ?q=expression1;expression2

You can use these queryable attributes to filter this collection resource using the q query parameter:
  • ChangeOrderTypeId; integer; Unique identifier of the change order type used for the item class.
  • DefaultItemClassFlag; boolean; Default item classes for items created through import will be picked based on this option. Only one item class can have this option enabled.
  • Description; string; Description of the item class.
  • EnabledFlag; boolean; Contains one of the following values: true or false. If true, then the item class is enabled for use. If false, then the item class isn't enabled for use. The default value is true.
  • InternalName; string; Internal name of the item class.
  • ItemClass; string; Name of the item class.
  • ItemClassCode; string; Internal name of an item class.
  • ItemClassId; integer; Unique identifier for an item class.
  • ItemClassType; string; Type of item class.
  • ItemCreationAllowedFlag; boolean; Contains one of the following values: true or false. If true, then items can be created in this item class. If false, then items can't be created in this item class. The default value is true.
  • ItemDescriptionGenMethodCode; string; Specifies the item description generation method for the items of the item class.
  • ItemDescriptionGenMethodValue; string; Attribute used to specify the item description generation method for the items of the item class.
  • ItemNumberGenMethodCode; string; Specifies the item number generation method for the items of the item class
  • ItemNumberGenMethodValue; string; An attribute used to specify the item number generation method for items created in the item class.
  • NewItemRequestRequiredFlag; boolean; Contains one of the following values: true or false. If true, then a new item request is required for items of the item class. If false, then a new item request isn't required for items of the item class.
  • ParentItemClass; string; Name of the parent item class.
  • ParentItemClassDescription; string; Description of the parent item class.
  • ParentItemClassId; integer; Parent item class of the child item class.
  • PublicFlag; boolean; Contains one of the following values: true or false. If true, then this item class can be used by all users. If false, this item class can't be used by all users. The default value is true.
